statement: Given triangle \( ABC \), the point \( J \) is the centre of the excircle opposite the vertex \( A \). This excircle is tangent to the side \( BC \) at \( M \), and to the lines \( AB \) and \( AC \) at \( K \) and \( L \), respectively. The lines \( LM \) and \( BJ \) meet at \( F \), and the lines \( KM \) and \( CJ \) meet at \( G \). Let \( S \) be the point of intersection of the lines \( AF \) and \( BC \), and let \( T \) be the point of intersection of the lines \( AG \) and \( BC \). Prove that \( M \) is the midpoint of \( ST \). (The excircle of \( ABC \) opposite the vertex \( A \) is the circle that is tangent to the line segment \( BC \), to the ray \( AB \) beyond \( B \), and to the ray \( AC \) beyond \( C \).)
Let \( n \geq 3 \) be an integer, and let \( a_2, a_3, \ldots, a_n \) be positive real numbers such that \(a_2 a_3 \cdots a_n = 1\). Prove that \((1 + a_2)^2 (1 + a_3)^3 \cdots (1 + a_n)^n > n^n\).

The liar's guessing game is played between two players \( A \) and \( B \). The rules depend on two positive integers \( k \) and \( n \). At the start, player \( A \) chooses integers \( x \) and \( N \) with \( 1 \leq x \leq N \), keeps \( x \) secret, and tells \( N \) to player \( B \). Player \( B \) asks questions of the following type: he specifies a set \( S \) of positive integers and asks whether \( x \in S \). Player \( A \) must answer yes or no, but may lie arbitrarily, subject to the restriction that among any \( k + 1 \) consecutive answers, at least one is truthful. After asking questions, player \( B \) specifies a set \( X \) of at most \( n \) positive integers. If \( x \in X \), then \( B \) wins; otherwise, \( B \) loses. Prove that: (1) If \( n \geq 2^k \), then \( B \) can guarantee a win. (2) For all sufficiently large \( k \), there exists an integer \( n \geq 1.99^k \) such that \( B \) cannot guarantee a win.

Find all functions \( f : \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z} \) such that, for all integers \( a, b, c \) satisfying \( a + b + c = 0 \), the equality \(f(a)^2 + f(b)^2 + f(c)^2 = 2f(a)f(b) + 2f(b)f(c) + 2f(c)f(a)\) holds. (Here \( \mathbb{Z} \) denotes the set of integers.)

Let \( ABC \) be a triangle with \( \angle BCA = 90^{\circ} \), and let \( D \) be the foot of the altitude from \( C \). Let \( X \) be a point in the interior of segment \( CD \). Let \( K \) be the point on segment \( AX \) such that \( BK = BC \). Similarly, let \( L \) be the point on segment \( BX \) such that \( AL = AC \). Let \( M \) be the point of intersection of \( AL \) and \( BK \). Show that \( MK = ML \).

Find all positive integers \( n \) for which there exist non-negative integers \( a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n \) such that \(\frac{1}{2^{a_1}} + \frac{1}{2^{a_2}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{2^{a_n}} = \frac{1}{3^{a_1}} + \frac{2}{3^{a_2}} + \cdots + \frac{n}{3^{a_n}} = 1\).
